heading: 1 Introduction
text:
guide team effort curating insights solutions implementing
integrated step selection analyses (iSSAs) synthesizing past experiences,
best practices, key resources. Given difficult start 
integrated step selection analysis choices need made, 
created approachable gateway world iSSAs. hope 
putting everything together help others. Please get touch 
questions comments, suggested edits.guide integrates functions outputs targets-iSSA
workflow. targets manages 
relationships data, variables intermediate outputs, well 
functions generate , ensures outdated objects regenerated.
also provides helpers flexibly batching steps across individuals, study
periods regions. Using targets workflow like one helped us
running iSSAs caching data processing, saving computation time, 
programatically identifying dropping individuals time periods cause
us headaches breaking runs outside type workflow. Starting 
workflow, users can swap data, variables, questions without
reinvent wheel.

# Data --------------------------------------------------------------------
# Path to fisher locs data
locs_path <- file.path('input', 'fisher.csv')

# Path to land cover, legend
lc_path <- file.path('input', 'lc.tif')
legend_path <- file.path('input', 'fisher_legend.csv')

# Path to elevation
elev_path <- file.path('input', 'elev.tif')

# Path to population density
popdens_path <- file.path('input', 'popdens.tif')

# Path to water
water_path <- file.path('input', 'water.gpkg')

# Variables ---------------------------------------------------------------
# Targets: prepare
id_col <- 'id'
datetime_col <- 't_'
x_col <- 'x_'
y_col <- 'y_'
epsg <- 32618
crs <- st_crs(epsg)
crs_sp <- CRS(crs$wkt)
tz <- 'America/New_York'

# Targets: tracks
# Split by: within which column or set of columns (eg. c(id, yr))
#  do we want to split our analysis?
split_by <- id_col

# Resampling rate
rate <- minutes(30)

# Tolerance
tolerance <- minutes(5)

# Number of random steps
n_random_steps <- 10

text: amt package includes code guidelines data cleaning, Bjørneraas et al. (2010).major GPS cleaning considerations :censor locations pre- post- animal capture collaringlow quality data (based available measure precision, 2D/3D, DPOP, etc.)unreachable habitats occupyunrealistic step lengthsimmediate round tripsdrop offs/ mortalities

heading: 3.2.2 Rarefication and Autocorrelation
text:
early GPS RSF studies, autocorrelation viewed issue directly
eliminate. last two decades, however, discourse around
autocorrelation become nuanced (Fieberg et al. 2021; Northrup et al. 2022). summarize current understanding, locations indeed ‘serially
dependent’ – points closer time closer space (Fleming et al. 2014). However, locations taken regular intervals, 
representative space use (Fieberg et al. 2021). Sampling locations 
regular intervals best practice habitat selection analyses. ,
autocorrelation bias reduce estimate uncertainty (SE). address
concern, using robust calculation confidence intervals can completed.

targets-issa workflow flexibly sample relevant spatial layers.
example, samples land cover (point), elevation (point),
population density (point), water (distance ). also

code:
# R/extract_layers.R
extract_layersfunction (DT, crs, lc, legend, elev, popdens, water) 
{
    setDT(DT)
    start <- c("x1_", "y1_")
    end <- c("x2_", "y2_")
    extract_pt(DT, lc, end)
    DT[legend, `:=`(lc_description, description), on = .(pt_lc = Value)]
    extract_pt(DT, elev, end)
    extract_pt(DT, popdens, end)
    extract_distance_to(DT, water, end, crs)
}

heading: 5.2.1 Relative Selection Strength
text:
Calculated animal selecting one spatial location (x1) another (x2) two locations except one habitat covariateCommon RSS expressions Avgar et al. (2017), formulation depends covariates interest modelCan use predict function: https://rdrr.io/cran/amt/man/log_rss.html amt JWT code (see Full workflow example)Fieberg ‘-’ goes RSS maths (Fieberg et al. 2021)targets-issa workflow, predict H1, H2 forest using
following functions:can calculate RSS forest:finally, plots plot_rss function.
code:
# R/predict_h1_water.R
predict_h1_waterfunction (DT, model) 
{
    N <- 100L
    new_data <- DT[, .(sl_ = mean(sl_), forest = 0, disturbed = 0, 
        dist_to_water = seq(from = 0, to = 1500, length.out = N), 
        indiv_step_id = NA), by = id]
    new_data[, `:=`(h1_water, predict(model, .SD, type = "link", 
        re.form = NULL))]
    new_data[, `:=`(x, seq(from = 0, to = 1500, length.out = N)), 
        by = id]
}
# R/predict_h2.R
predict_h2function (DT, model) 
{
    new_data <- DT[, .(sl_ = mean(sl_), forest = 0, disturbed = 0, 
        dist_to_water = median(dist_to_water, na.rm = TRUE), 
        indiv_step_id = NA), by = id]
    new_data[, `:=`(h2, predict(model, .SD, type = "link", re.form = NULL))]
}
# R/calc_rss.R
calc_rssfunction (pred_h1, h1_col, pred_h2, h2_col) 
{
    log_rss <- merge(pred_h1[, .SD, .SDcols = c("id", "x", h1_col)], 
        pred_h2[, .SD, .SDcols = c("id", h2_col)], by = "id", 
        all.x = TRUE)
    log_rss[, `:=`(rss, h1 - h2), env = list(h1 = h1_col, h2 = h2_col)]
}
tar_read(plot_rss_forest)## `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula 'y ~ x'

# Targets: prepare
id_col <- 'id'
datetime_col <- 't_'
x_col <- 'x_'
y_col <- 'y_'
epsg <- 32618
crs <- st_crs(epsg)
crs_sp <- CRS(crs$wkt)
tz <- 'America/New_York'

# Targets: tracks

split_by <- id_col

# Resampling rate
rate <- minutes(30)

# Tolerance
tolerance <- minutes(5)

# Number of random steps
n_random_steps <- 10

code:
# R/extract_layers.R
extract_layersfunction (DT, crs, lc, legend, elev, popdens, water) 
{
    setDT(DT)
    start <- c("x1_", "y1_")
    end <- c("x2_", "y2_")
    extract_pt(DT, lc, end)
    DT[legend, `:=`(lc_description, description), on = .(pt_lc = Value)]
    extract_pt(DT, elev, end)
    extract_pt(DT, popdens, end)
    extract_distance_to(DT, water, end, crs)
}

# R/model_land_cover.R
model_land_coverfunction (DT) 
{
    glmmTMB(case_ ~ -1 + I(log(sl_)) + I(log(sl_)):lc_adj + lc_adj + 
        I(log(dist_to_water + 1)) + I(log(dist_to_water + 1)):I(log(sl_)) + 
        (1 | indiv_step_id) + (0 + I(log(sl_)) | id) + (0 + I(log(sl_)):lc_adj | 
        id) + (0 + lc_adj | id) + (0 + I(log(dist_to_water + 
        1)) | id) + (0 + I(log(dist_to_water + 1)):I(log(sl_)) | 
        id), data = DT, family = poisson(), map = list(theta = factor(c(NA, 
        1:23))), start = list(theta = c(log(1000), seq(0, 0, 
        length.out = 23))))
}

# R/model_forest_bin.R
model_forest_binfunction (DT) 
{
    glmmTMB(case_ ~ -1 + I(log(sl_)) + I(log(sl_)):forest + forest + 
        I(log(sl_)):disturbed + disturbed + I(log(dist_to_water + 
        1)) + I(log(dist_to_water + 1)):I(log(sl_)) + (1 | indiv_step_id) + 
        (0 + I(log(sl_)) | id) + (0 + I(log(sl_)):disturbed | 
        id) + (0 + I(log(sl_)):forest | id) + (0 + forest | id) + 
        (0 + disturbed | id) + (0 + I(log(dist_to_water + 1)) | 
        id) + (0 + I(log(dist_to_water + 1)):I(log(sl_)) | id), 
        data = DT, family = poisson(), map = list(theta = factor(c(NA, 
            1:7))), start = list(theta = c(log(1000), seq(0, 
            0, length.out = 7))))
}

give idea speed, partial show effect size (
phrased well – fix). using gamma distribution iSSA, 
mean estimated speed shape parameter multiplied scale parameter 
gamma distribution. However, shape modified movement variables
iSSA . calculation becomes\(\text{mean estimated speed} = (shape + logSL.beta + logSLintx.beta*mean(.interacted.))*scale\), toy example, done . , can pick

interacted . seq represents range values ’re looking .Let’s see fishers’ speed changes areas without anthropogenic disturbance vs areas disturbed (seq = 0:1)
